title: Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | SB 1.13.58 - 60 | 5-11-2022
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.key_quote: for the woman the fire of separation from her husband is more intolerable than the fire of the burning of the husband's dead body so she decides to quit voluntarily and such quitting the body voluntarily is considered to be the most successful way to get her body into
segments.summary: This segment explains Gandhari's decision to enter the fire of her dead husband, known as the Sati rite, highlighting it as a voluntary act of a chaste wife who finds separation from her husband more unbearable than death.

segments.key_quote: in a later age this sati rite became an obnoxious criminal affair it became criminal why because the ceremony was forced upon even an unwilling woman see mind you it is totally voluntary
segments.summary: This segment discusses the historical context of the Sati rite, emphasizing that it should be a voluntary act and condemning the practice of forcing widows to commit Sati as a criminal act.

segments.key_quote: a chaste wife like gandhari would feel the separation of her husband to be more burning than actual fire such a lady can actually observe the sati right voluntarily and there is no criminal being forced by anyone
segments.summary: This segment explains that in the present age, the Sati rite is not possible for anyone to follow unless the wife feels the separation from her husband to be more burning than actual fire, and that by following her husband, she can attain liberation without separate spiritual practices.

segments.key_quote: An offence at the feet of a Vaishnava is more dangerous than an offence at the feet of the Lord. Vidhara was certainly very liberal to bestow mercy upon Dhritarashtra whose past life was very materialistic but ultimately the result of all such mercy depends on the will of the Lord who grants spiritual advancement, who grants spiritual liberation, who grants spiritual benefits.
segments.summary: This segment discusses Gandhari's wonderful destination, Vidura's mixed feelings about Dhritarashtra's liberation, and the importance of the Lord's will in granting spiritual advancement, emphasizing that offenses to Vaishnavas are more dangerous than offenses to the Lord.

segments.key_quote: Devotees may help, devotees may guide, devotees may direct, devotees may inspire but devotees cannot give anything. It is the Lord only who gives.
segments.summary: This segment emphasizes that while devotees can guide and inspire, only the Lord can grant spiritual advancement and liberation, and that proper surrender to Krishna requires many lifetimes of understanding one's spiritual identity.

segments.key_quote: Having spoken thus, the great sage Nārada, along with his veena, ascended into outer space. Yuriṣṭira kept his instruction in his heart and so was able to get to the fall lamentation.
segments.summary: This segment discusses Narada's ascension to outer space, Yudhishthira's overcoming lamentation through Narada's instructions, and Narada's role as an eternal spaceman who travels to preach the message of Krishna and liberate people.

segments.key_quote: You should follow in the footsteps of Nārada Muni. Become a devotee and go back to the spiritual kingdom of Kṛṣṇa.
segments.summary: This segment encourages listeners to follow Narada Muni's example by becoming devotees and returning to the spiritual kingdom of Krishna to engage in loving devotional service.
